message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The child has already undergone behavioral therapy, but the enuresis persists, so it’s time to move onto other treatment modalities. DDAVP and Oxybutynin are not appropriate because they have not been shown to be effective for monosymptomatic enuresis. Enuresis alarm is the most appropriate next step as it is effective in 60-80% of cases and has no side effects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Since the first-line therapy of behavioral therapy has already been attempted and the enuresis persists, the next step would be to try a medication. DDAVP can be used, but it has potential side effects such as hyponatremia, so an enuresis alarm, which is non-invasive and has no side effects, would be the most appropriate next step. Oxybutynin is used for overactive bladder and is not indicated in enuresis.

DDAVP and oxybutynin are medications used to treat enuresis, but are not the most appropriate next step in this case.

The next step would be to try a pharmacological approach, and DDAVP and Oxybutynin have been shown to be effective in some cases. However, the most appropriate next step in management for this patient would be to try an enuresis alarm, as it has been shown to be the most effective second-line treatment for monosymptomatic enuresis.

DDAVP and Oxybutynin are not recommended as first-line treatment for primary monosymptomatic enuresis in children. DDAVP and oxybutynin are options, but since the patient has no daytime symptoms and the main issue is nighttime bedwetting, an enuresis alarm is the most appropriate next step.
